DOCNAME: CASE OF AKDENIZ AND OTHERS v. TURKEY
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 2 with State's liability for death of eleven missing persons;Violation of Art. 2 with regard to failure to conduct an effective investigation;Violation of Art. 3 with regard to the missing persons;No violation of Art. 3 with regard to the applicants;Violation of Art. 5-1;Violation of Art. 13;Failure to comply with obligations under Art. 34;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The facts of the case , particularly concerning events during DATE when security forces conducted an operation in the LOC in south - east GPE , were disputed by the parties . ORG , pursuant to former LAW ( a ) of the LAW , conducted an investigation with the assistance of the parties .

CARDINAL . Alaca village may be described as an area of dispersed hamlets and houses spread over mountainous terrain , which for administrative purposes was regarded as being in the GPE district . Its hamlets included PERSON ( where PERSON , PERSON and PERSON lived ) , PERSON ( where PERSON , his brother PERSON and son PERSON , PERSON and PERSON were said to live ) , PERSON ( where PERSON lived ) , GPE and ORG . Nearby but in the LOC was GPE , including GPE hamlet ( where PERSON and ORG stated that they lived with their brother PERSON ; PERSON also said he lived there with his father PERSON ; PERSON lived there ) .

CARDINAL . Alaca village was not far from LOC ( NORP ) , where some people led a nomadic style of life and where there were fruit and walnut trees ( PERSON stated that he lived there and PERSON was stated to have pastures there , living a nomadic life with other members of his family ) . The nearest gendarme station was at PERSON , which was on the ORG . Many of the applicants and members of their families were also living in either ORG , the CARDINAL nearest large towns . Some distance to the south of Alaca was GPE of which PERSON was the muhtar .

CARDINAL . In DATE , terrorist activity was a major concern in this area . There were several ORG bases in the vicinity of Alaca . PERSON , the commander of NORP station , stated that his station had been attacked several times . The GPE district gendarme commander Captain PERSON stated that there was intensive terrorist activity in the GPE area . General PERSON of the Bolu brigade described the area as being the backbone of the NORP activities , and explained that his forces were involved in many operations there . An undated final operation report ( Commission report , paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) described the LOC as the largest training area for the ORG . According to this report , it had fortified defences and enjoyed the support of PERCENT of the hamlets and villages in the region , the villagers from which supplied the ORG with shelter and food . Villagers also used to go into the towns to buy food for the terrorists .

CARDINAL . By DATE , many people from in and around LOC had left or were about to leave either due to the difficulty of life in the remote mountainous area or due to the security situation . The Commission rejected the evidence of the gendarme witnesses that the area had already been abandoned . The weight of the evidence showed that a significant number of families were still living there , while other villagers from this area continued to move to and from the mountains to the town seasonally . Some , like PERSON and PERSON , were nomadic herders .

CARDINAL . From DATE , the Bolu brigade assisted by gendarmerie forces conducted a massive military operation . On the evidence of the commanding officer , General PERSON , this involved CARDINAL soldiers and helicopters . Its purpose was to converge soldiers from bases in the GPE and GPE districts on the NORP area to apprehend terrorists and locate their bases , stores and weapons dumps . The operation lasted until DATE . The Government and the applicants were at variance however as to the events which occurred concerning the villagers during the operation .

CARDINAL . The Commission noted that the conflict lay between the ORG ’s assertion , supported by the security force witnesses , that the missing persons had been kidnapped by the ORG dressed as soldiers and that the families in introducing the applications were acting as the pawns of the ORG , motivated by fear or a desire to obtain financial gain ; and the assertion of the applicants and their families that their relatives had been detained by soldiers during the operation and last seen being taken away by helicopter . The credibility and reliability of the witnesses was the crucial issue .

CARDINAL . The Commission , relying on its Delegates , found the applicants and the members of their family and the villager PERSON were honest and convincing in the way they gave their evidence . Some were confused about details , in particular about dates , which was not unexpected due to the lapse of time . Some of the women witnesses and PERSON were simple , unsophisticated individuals who were answering sincerely to the best of their ability . The Commission commented that all the applicants showed deep and abiding distress at the uncertainty which they had suffered after the disappearance of their relatives , several making appeals that they might at last be told the fate of their family members . Their evidence was strongly consistent with supporting documentary material , including petitions made by the families shortly after the events and the reliability of this considerable weight of evidence was confirmed as more witnesses were heard . In significant aspects , it was also substantiated by the villager witnesses brought forward by the Government .

CARDINAL . Conversely , ORG received a negative impression from the gendarme witnesses , PERSON and PERSON . Their evidence , which included the denials that there was any operation in the area at the time , was shown to be unreliable when the General PERSON informed the Delegates that there was such an operation and indicated that both would have been aware . While ORG impressed as a forceful and competent witness , his evidence was given under circumstances which diminished its weight , as the ORG refused to allow the applicant ’s representatives to be present when he gave evidence to the Delegates . He showed reluctance to address the factual concerns of the ORG , avoiding precise answers . It found doubts arose as to the reliability of his evidence on the treatment of the villagers , the use of helicopters and the claim that no soldiers went into the villages or hamlets in the Alaca area . It examined the alleged points of inconsistency in the ORG versions of events put forward by the Government . It found that some differences in detail were explicable by the lapse of time and that they were not of such a nature as to undermine the applicants or the witnesses’ credibility . Their accounts were essentially consistent , credible and reliable .
CARDINAL . On that basis , the ORG found as follows .

CARDINAL . Soon after the operation started , the soldiers began collecting villagers together , for use as guides to show them the location of settlements and ORG shelters and stores , for questioning about involvement with the ORG and for possible transfer to detention elsewhere .

CARDINAL . Villagers were first taken into custody on or near LOC on DATE , the soldiers arriving at ORG on CARDINAL October . Some villagers were looked for by name . Others were gathered generally for an identity check . The soldiers set up a camp at GPE , a hill close to the hamlet of PERSON , where helicopters landed , inter alia , to bring in supplies . There were other camps set up , CARDINAL or CARDINAL near GPE and GPE and another near the GPE district boundary , where villagers were held for DATE .

CARDINAL . PERSON , who was DATE , was not from the Alaca village . He is known to have been detained by the police when he arrived in GPE on or DATE . His brother PERSON arrived in GPE , paying visits to him . According to the official documents provided , in particular a release statement of DATE apparently bearing PERSON thumbprint , he ceased to be in police custody at that date . According to the evidence of his father , the applicant PERSON , PERSON arrived to visit him but was told by the police that he had been released . CARDINAL . The applicant alleges that in making enquiries he was told that his son had been handed over to the forces from Bolu who were on an operation . He also heard from nomads that his son had been seen tied up outside the NORP station and that from there he had been taken to PERSON . When he visited PERSON , people there told him that they had seen his son with the other detainees held at GPE .

CARDINAL . The evidence before the Delegates concerning PERSON showed that he was not known by any of the applicants and witnesses . Several witnesses referred to seeing a person , not from the village , being detained with the other CARDINAL . Others only knew of the name PERSON when his father came looking for him after events . PERSON gave eye - witness evidence that he saw PERSON , detained with them TIME at ORG and taken with them to GPE . However , he did not talk to the young man himself . He stated that PERSON and PERSON who were with the young man , told him that his name was PERSON .

CARDINAL . The Commission observed that there were difficulties in the evidence concerning the identification of PERSON , in particular the differing ages estimated by the persons who saw him . However this could be accounted for , inter alia , by the fact that ill - treatment or living rough over a period of time could change a person ’s appearance dramatically . In light of the firm identification of PERSON , supported by the evidence of ORG who had heard from his brother PERSON that PERSON was in the group of TIME and the written statement of DATE by PERSON naming PERSON as a young boy caught in GPE who had been held with him , the Commission was satisfied that these elements were sufficiently coherent and consistent to establish beyond reasonable doubt that he was the eleventh detainee .

CARDINAL . At GPE , the villagers were held in different groups , to which different restrictions applied . CARDINAL of them ( the persons who later disappeared ) were kept in CARDINAL group . They were tied up , though they were untied for visits , or when they ate or relieved themselves . CARDINAL witnesses ( PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON ) however stated that PERSON , though of this group , was not tied up . Other detainees – PERSON , PERSON DATE were held in a group of CARDINAL villagers , who were not tied up . They were kept in the camp during DATE and sent to houses in PERSON to spend the night . PERSON and PERSON , who were tied up , were held with or near the group of TIME .
CARDINAL . As concerning the way in which the QUANTITY men were treated at GPE , the ORG found that :
– the QUANTITY persons , save PERSON , were tied up ( PERSON described that her relatives’ toes were swollen as a result ) ;
– they were kept outside during DATE and at TIME ( PERSON was seen to be flushed , shaking , his lips chapped and to be affected by the cold ) ;
– they were questioned by the soldiers ;

– they were in a state of some distress and apprehension ( PERSON was described as hungry , thirsty and miserable ; PERSON told others that he was in a terrible state and feared that they were going to be killed ; PERSON evidence referred to the detainees being in a miserable state , having gone hungry and been tied up for DATE ) ;
– PERSON and PERSON were taken from the group by helicopter apparently to act as guides or show locations ;
– PERSON was taken away from the group for DATE or CARDINAL and on his return was seen to be limping and needing the support of soldiers to walk ;
– PERSON was also taken away to Şen pastures to act as a guide ;
– money ( CARDINAL GPE ) was taken from PERSON by the soldiers ;

CARDINAL . There was insufficient evidence to establish that the CARDINAL men were subject to torture under interrogation . There was some evidence of beating of the detainees ( PERSON witnessed his brother PERSON being beaten ) , but the nature and extent of the beating was not apparent .

CARDINAL . By a date about DATE , all the detainees at GPE , save CARDINAL , had been released . Descriptions were given of a selection process where names were called out and those persons released . Some of the remaining detainees were seen being placed in helicopters . The Commission observed that the timing of this event is problematic , the evidence of the principal witnesses being vague or confused on this point . The weight of the evidence placed the last sighting of the remaining CARDINAL detainees at CARDINAL October but this can only be regarded as approximate .

CARDINAL . The eye - witness evidence as to whom was seen being taken away was also not clear . PERSON referred to seeing ORG and his friends being put on the helicopter but that it was too far to see . PERSON referred to QUANTITY persons . She did not know PERSON and if he was there she was not in a position to identify him . She stated specifically that she could see PERSON and PERSON being put on the helicopter . The Commission noted that the applicants and the other witnesses appeared to associate the placing of detainees on the helicopter with their missing relatives largely because some were identified by the women and also on the basis that these QUANTITY persons were the only detainees remaining at GPE after the others such as ORG and PERSON were released . They had also been held together as a distinct group and were no longer there after the operation ended . While this provided strong circumstantial evidence , the Commission was not satisfied that it could be established , to the necessary standard of proof , that the CARDINAL missing persons were all placed on the helicopters , in particular PERSON , though it was satisfied that at least some of the QUANTITY detainees were . There was no evidence that any of these persons were seen after the operation ended on or about DATE . The Commission found that when they were last seen they were detained under guard by security forces .

A public prosecutor who is informed by any means whatsoever of a situation that gives rise to the suspicion that an offence has been committed is obliged to investigate the facts in order to decide whether or not there should be a prosecution ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . In the case of alleged terrorist offences , the public prosecutor is deprived of jurisdiction in favour of a separate system of ORG prosecutors and courts established throughout GPE .

In such cases it is for the relevant local administrative council ( for the district or province , depending on the suspect ’s status ) to conduct the preliminary investigation and , consequently , to decide whether to prosecute . Once a decision to prosecute has been taken , it is for the public prosecutor to investigate the case .
An appeal to ORG lies against a decision of the ORG . If a decision not to prosecute is taken , the case is automatically referred to that court .
